instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Hey everyone - i've been doing this work for a few years now, but have registered because i'm totally stuck on a board.

So I had a guy come in for a battery replacement the other day - i went to plug it in and realised that it wasn't working off the charger either - he hadn't picked up that this wasn't a battery issue.

I swapped in another battery out of interest and it booted up fine - no boot from charger tho, and no charging of the battery.

[B]The Facts[/B]
No green light on charger.
SMC reset does nothing.
PRAM reset did nothing either.
Tried with multiple known-good magsafe boards and chargers - all good there.
Customer now believes problem was caused by a knock-off charger.
Absolutely no sign of liquid damage.
With one of my 18.5 volt chargers, i get a random green light, sometimes with a faint ticking sound from the board - the charger looks 100% genuine, but i'm starting to think it is fake because both other chargers give me no green light and no ticking. All three chargers behave normally with other macbooks.

[B]The diagnosis & repair work done so far[/B]
I have replaced <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> because they were all screwed with high resistance. I have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. I also replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> for good measure.
Since doing the above, the device now boots in SMC Bypass mode with charger, but still nothing otherwise.

[B]Some helpful measurements taken[/B]
Resistance between pins 17&18 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> = 3.5Ω
Resistance between pins 27&28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> = 20Ω
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> = 3.44v
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> = 3.44v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.45
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.54v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0.00v

Device still boots perfectly on battery, correctly identifies cycles etc and runs at full speed with normal fans - no boot on charger, and no charge. I'm starting to suspect the SMC, please tell me it's not the SMC, please...
HALP!

Thanks,
V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message: Certainly garbage Chinese charger damage. You've done all there is to do, last two options before the SMC are <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01. <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85 sometimes cause issues, but my gut feelings says dead SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
So, i replaced <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 and it made no difference. I bit the bullet and replaced the SMC - but still no difference! Exactly the same symptoms with the replacement SMC.

Weirdly, with the new SMC <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> now measures 12.57v, but i'd assume the extra 0.03v is not a problem.

Any other ideas to try?

EDIT: I've discovered that when the battery is plugged in too - the magsafe light is actually very dully lit green - don't know if that helps at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message: Must be crap under the magsafe connector on the board then. There is not much else to this. I assume you are 100% sure about a good magsafe board and charger? There must be some leak resistance/capacitance on the <SIGNAL>ONE_WIRE</SIGNAL> line that kills communication with the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Yeah i just tried yet another magsafe, taken from a machine it is currently working in - still not working. I just don't understand :'(.

Any suggestions of places i could check for leak resistance/capacitance on the one-wire? i will re-solder the magsafe connector on board but im pretty sure it's not that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Checked <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>? Besides that and corrosion under the connector there is not much else you can do. The problem can also be inside the board.
You can remove <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and then check diode mode on <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> to see if the trace to the SMC is in tact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
I've checked <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> - it's a solid 2k
There's no corrosion anywhere on the board. 
I removed <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and used diode mode, red on ground, black on <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> - i got 0.7v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message: I've noticed that when i start up the board with just the battery, keyboard and screen connected, that the fans seem to blare up to full speed - kinda like when SMC bypass is on, but they gradually do it during the bootup. Perhaps the other SMC i've put on is also faulty :/. I'm guessing a replacement SMC has to come from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board? I've only got one in the donor pile and i've already taken its SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="victor, post: 29408"]I've noticed that when i start up the board with just the battery, keyboard and screen connected, that the fans seem to blare up to full speed - kinda like when SMC bypass is on, but they gradually do it during the bootup. Perhaps the other SMC i've put on is also faulty :/. I'm guessing a replacement SMC has to come from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board? I've only got one in the donor pile and i've already taken its SMC.[/QUOTE]

This means you have one or more sensors failing so the SMC is running the CPU in low speed while blasting the fans on full. What does ASD tell you about the sensors? Just wondering.
EDIT: Check duke's response

You indeed need to get a SMC from a exact identical board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
No need to check anything, without trackpad connected the fan will run at full speed.

I have no other ideas then a dead SMC or issue inside the board. I assume you replaced the magsafe board connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Ah yes - the fan thing was indeed simply the trackpad not being connected.

I haven't actually replaced the magsafe connector on the board - it looked absolutely perfect and there's no corrosion anywhere so i just re-soldered the pins on the board. I figured since it's just a dumb 5-pin connection, there ain't much that could be wrong with it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message: It could have crap hiding under it. There are no other options besides a problem inside the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Well, I've given up. I replaced the connector and still no luck. There doesn't seem to be a problem inside the board as each line is present in every place it's meant to be present. It's a mystery forever i guess. Maybe the other SMC i have is also faulty, i'll never know as i have no more <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B SMCS and there ain't none on eBay either.

Thanks a lot for your time regardless Duke, it was nice getting closer to having some form of closure with this board lol.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message:
Proving voltages are there does not rule out a board issue. There could be resistive/capacitive leaks inside the board messing up the signal. It is not just a voltage on the onewire line, it is serial communication.
You could hook up the scope and look at the data pulses on the onewire bus and compare with a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Only Working from Battery + No Green Light
threads.message: Very interesting! I will do exactly that and report.
